Award.AwardTitle: An Adaptive and Robust Discrete Geometry Based Helmholtz Solver and Applications to Device Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is the development of mathematics and algorithms that facilitate design and optimization of physical systems that are governed by the Helmholtz equation. While the research results are broadly applicable, the focus of this effort will be restricted to acoustic and electromagnetic systems. The crux of the proposed effort will rely on developing solution techniques that are capable of multiscale analysis, and are highly flexible and adaptive in both surface and function representation. The research progresses in sequence through three stages; the development of (i) local parametric surface descriptors that can be adaptively refined, (ii) a functional framework to represent fields and corresponding integral equation solvers, and (iii) hierarchical algorithms for morphing surfaces in response to external constraints. The methods developed will be used in three application areas; nanophotonics, steering of microbubbles and shape reconstruction in inverse problems. Deliverables include a highly flexible and adaptive modeling and analysis tool, demonstration and validation via applications, documentation and dissemination of research results, and cross-disciplinary student education.

Tthe results of this research will provide a cogent modeling tool that is sufficiently flexible and adaptive so as to be usable within a design and optimization framework for Helmholtz systems. To highlight their broad applicability, the tools developed will be tested in different types of applications ranging from biomimetic displays to solar cells to microbubbles to inverse problems in imaging. To ensure dissemination of the research, the PIs will create a dedicated website, as well as work with the Michigan Center of Industrial and Applied Mathematics and Institute of Cyber-Enabled Research. Existing channels in women and minority recruitment at MSU will be utilized. Undergraduate students will be involved through senior design projects and through existing REU programs at MSU. Graduate and Undergraduate Engineering, Computer Science and Physics students will benefit through classroom instruction and involvement in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the project was to develop a computational framework that would enable design and analysis of physical phenomena that is governed by the wave/Helmholtz equation. Auxiliary to this was examining applications of the technology that was developed to a set of interesting problems, the foremost of which is trapping and steering of microbubbles. 

Intellectual Impact: We have accomplished above and beyond what we proposed. As the project progressed, we systematically tackled many of the fundamental bottlenecks. These include both fundamental (F) and applied (A) issues; these are indicated as such in the description that follows. The foremost of the challenges is developing equations that is well behaved (F) at frequencies of interest, developing a method for discretizing and solving these equations using highly adaptive framework (F & A) such as those offered by the computer graphics community, and developing an accurate and fast method for evaluating the inner products necessary to create a matrix system (A).  All of these are key building blocks; the first provides the necessary physics but behaves well so as to enable exploration of the design space, the second marries the representation of both the physics and geometry so as to have the fewest degrees of freedom, and the last ensures that the discrete system accurately represents the true continuous system. The methods developed have been disseminated via several journal papers. In addition, we embarked on transient scattering analysis, inspired by one of the goals of the paper-steering of microbubbles. In doing so, we solved a problem that has been unsolved to any degree of satisfaction for almost 60 years--viz., transient scattering from spheres (acoustic and electromagnetic) using quasi-analytical methods (F). We used a variation of this procedure to show how spheres can be trapped and understood collective motion when subject to an acoustic pulse (A), by integrating the techniques developed with molecular dynamics. Such work when integrated with cavitation models can have immediate impact on mechanisms for drug delivery. 

Broader Impact: The most significant broader impact of the work has been the mentoring of students. A total of four graduate students (all PhD) have been mentored with partial support from this project. Of the four, one has started work at the US Air Force, the other is pursuing a post-doc at CalTech, the last two are about graduate and enter the workforce with companies who specialize in using wave phenomena. We have also used the money to fund a series of Undergraduate researchers who have been with group for varied durations of time. Most significantly, three of these students have started their PhDs (two in my group and one in USC). One of these students won three graduate fellowships (DOE-Krell, NDSEG, SMART) and is currently a second year student in my group. We have several publications (both conference and journal) where the material developed has been disseminated.
